introduction.p: In , we defined the cosine and sine functions in terms of x and y coordinates on the unit circle. We also defined the cosine and sine of an angle as ratios of the sides of a right triangle. Since a triangle has 3 sides, there are 6 possible combinations of ratios of side lengths. While cosine and sine are the two prominent ratios that can be formed, there are four others, and together they define the 6 trigonometric functions.

subsection.title: The Tangent Function

assemblage.title: The Definition of Tangent
assemblage.p: Note that since \sin(\theta)=y and \cos(\theta)=x, we can also define tangent as \tan(\theta)=\frac{\sin(\theta)}{\cos(\theta)}

subsection.p: We can find the tangent values of common angles on the unit circle by using the sine and cosine values of the angles (or the corresponding y and x coordinates).

solution.p: Since we know the sine and cosine values for 45^\circ, it makes sense to relate the tangent value back to the sine and cosine values.

From the definition of tangent, we have that \, \displaystyle \tan(\theta)=\frac{\sin(\theta)}{\cos(\theta)} \, so \tan(45^\circ)=\frac{\sin(45^\circ)}{\cos(45^\circ)}= \frac{\sqrt{2}/2}{\sqrt{2}/2} = 1

From the definition of tangent, we get that \tan\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)=\frac{\sin(\pi/3)}{\cos(\pi/3)}= \frac{\sqrt{3}/2}{1/2} = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{1} = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{1} = \sqrt{3}

statement.p: To find the height of a tree, a person walks to a point 30 feet from the base of the tree, and measures the angle from the ground to the top of the tree to be 57 degrees. Find the height of the tree.

solution.p: Let's start by drawing a picture of the situation and labeling the known information.

We can introduce a variable, h, to represent the height of the tree. The two sides of the triangle that are most important to us are the side opposite of the 57^\circ angle, which is the height of the tree that we are looking for, and the adjacent side, which is given as a distance of 30 feet.
The trigonometric function that relates the side opposite of the angle and the side adjacent to the angle is the tangent function. Using this function, we can set up an equation and solve to find h.
The tree is approximately 46.2 feet tall.

subsection.title: The Graph of the Tangent Function
subsection.p: Just like we did with the sine and cosine functions in , we can sketch a graph of the tangent function by creating a table of input and output values and plotting these points on a plane. Below is a table of values for f(\theta) = \tan(\theta) and its corresponding graph.

Notice that the output values of tangent repeat on a regular interval, so f(\theta) = \tan(\theta) is a periodic function. For any angle, there is a second angle halfway around the unit circle with the same tangent value. Therefore, the period of tangent is \pi. We can see one continuous cycle from -\pi/2 to \pi/2, before the graph jumps and repeats itself.

note.p: The graph of tangent has no maximum or minimum value. Therefore, as you may recall from , tangent is an example of a periodic function with no midline or amplitude.

statement.p: Explain how the tangent function is related to the slope of a line going through the origin and a point (x,y) on the unit circle.

solution.p: One way we can think about the graph of tangent is to relate the tangent function to the slope of a line going through the origin and a point (x,y) on the unit circle. Above, we defined tangent as \tan(\theta) = \frac{y}{x} where x and y are the coordinates of a point on the unit circle corresponding to a given angle \theta. Now, notice that y/x corresponds to the slope of a line through the origin. Therefore, the tangent of an angle, \theta, is equal to the slope of a line going through the origin making an angle of \theta with the positive x-axis.

We can also relate this concept to the graph of tangent. At an angle of 0, the line would be horizontal with a slope of zero. This corresponds to the value of \tan(0)=0, or where the graph of tangent passes through the origin. As the angle increases towards \pi/2, the slope of the line increases more and more. At an angle of \pi/2, the line would be vertical and the slope would be undefined. Immediately past \pi/2, the line would have a steep negative slope, corresponding to a large negative value of tangent. The undefined slope at \pi/2 corresponds to a vertical asymptote on the graph, where the tangent value jumps from a large positive value to a large negative value.

subsection.title: Reciprocal Trigonometric Functions
subsection.p: There are times when it can be useful to consider functions like 1/\sin(\theta) or 1/\cos(\theta). This happens often enough that mathematicians have created special names for these types of functions. Generally, these functions are called reciprocal trigonometric functions, and they can be defined in terms of the sine, cosine, and tangent functions.

subsection.p: You may have noticed in the previous example that \cos(\alpha) = \sin(\beta) and \cos(\beta) = \sin(\alpha). If we think about Soh-Cah-Toa and the right triangle relationships, the side opposite of \alpha is the side that is adjacent to \beta so it would make sense that \cos(\alpha) = \sin(\beta). Since the three angles in a triangle need to add to \pi, or 180 degrees, then the angles \alpha and \beta must add to \pi/2, or 90 degrees, so \alpha + \beta = \pi/2 and we have that \beta = \frac{\pi}{2} - \alpha \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} \alpha = \frac{\pi}{2}-\beta Since \cos(\alpha) = \sin(\beta), we get that \cos(\alpha) = \sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\alpha\right)

assemblage.title: Cofunctions
assemblage.p: Two angles are called cofunctionscofunctions if they are equal on complementary angles (angles that add up to 90 degrees or \pi/2 radians).

Sine and cosine are examples of cofunctions (hence the "co" in cosine). The cofunction identities for sine and cosine are \cos(\theta) = \sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\theta\right) \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} \sin(\theta) = \cos\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\theta\right)

Secant and cosecant are another example of cofunctions as are tangent and cotangent, which gives us two more sets of identities. \sec(\theta) = \csc\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\theta\right) \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} \csc(\theta) = \sec\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\theta\right) \tan(\theta) = \cot\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\theta\right) \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} \cot(\theta) = \tan\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\theta\right)
